image.altText: A stylised image of a partially obscured man's face with scrabble-style tiles flying towards him

props.synopsis: The ABC has identified James Raptis, a lawyer at Australian Community Media, as being linked to a series of websites that were stealing – and mangling – stories from other sites.

title.children: We asked this Australian lawyer if he was behind a 'parasitic' content farm. Hours later it was all taken down

image.altText: Thomas Brough stands during this year's Anzac Day service in Albany. He's wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: The WA Liberals' endorsement of an Albany doctor who made false claims about the LGBTQIA+ community is attracting the kind of attention the party doesn't need.

title.children: Why are WA Liberals backing a candidate whose comments they say don't reflect party values?

image.altText: Jim Chalmers during Labor caucus meeting__bfadb08a4ff478a0254b937808092f54

props.synopsis: The federal budget will deliver a $9.3 billion surplus for the current financial year, but the next three will each have higher deficits than the government had expected as recently as December.

title.children: Australia is set for a $9.3 billion surplus, but deficits for next three financial years

image.altText: An ankle monitor used by WA Police

props.synopsis: Protecting victims of domestic violence was promised to be a key plank of the WA budget, but there are concerns the measures do not go far enough to protect vulnerable women.

title.children: As the domestic violence epidemic continues unchecked, there are fears WA's budget didn't do enough for victims

image.altText: Jim Chalmers stands in front of a vibrant red tree.

props.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers will hand down his third federal budget tonight, but the government has been steadily drip-feeding key announcements for weeks. Here's everything we already know about what's inside.

title.children: It's budget day, but we don't have to wait to find out what's inside. Here's what we know

image.altText: Two  women walk past the Reserve Bank of Australia headquarters, with the building's name prominent in the background.

props.synopsis: Federal budgets have always been a juggling act, but inflation's belated second wind and a weakening economy means the treasurer must somehow encourage growth without making inflation any worse.

title.children: Competing interests mean this year's budget is the most confusing in years

image.altText: A young white woman with long fair hair standing in a field. She is wearing a green cardigan

props.synopsis: Dozens of patients have contacted the ABC, reporting alarming side effects including vomiting blood and permanent tingling in their fingers after taking replica weight loss drugs.

title.children: Ilisa was vomiting blood after injecting replica Ozempic. The pharmacy kept ringing to sell her more

image.altText: An aerial view of a house that has been destroyed by a ferocious storm.

props.synopsis: More than 220 properties have suffered some sort of damage from the tornado, which ripped through the southern suburbs of WA's largest regional city on Friday.

title.children: Residents return to roofless homes after freak tornado lays waste to Bunbury suburbs

image.altText: A large building with a white gate and a red flag flying outside

props.synopsis: Chinese police hunting international corruption targets were allowed into Australia by the federal police and subsequently escorted a woman back to China for trial, in a major breach of Chinese-Australian police protocols.

title.children: Politicians sound alarm about 'extrajudicial extradition' of Chinese-born Australian resident

image.altText: Prince Harry wearing a suit and sunglasses leans in to Meghan Markle wearing sunglasses and a yellow dress.

props.synopsis: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex's 72-hour visit to Nigeria has attracted a level of publicity Buckingham Palace has been sorely lacking of late. Is it a reminder of the "Harry-shaped hole in the monarchy?"

title.children: Harry and Meghan's Nigerian visit is a reminder of how much the House of Windsor could have used them

image.altText: A graphic showing a woman smiling in a selfie embeded on top of a photo of the front of a house with a police officer.

props.synopsis: A teenager gave a thumbs up before entering a family's home on Boxing Day. What followed destroyed a father and children, who could no longer sleep alone.

title.children: Emma Lovell was murdered by a teen in her front yard. Her family have had their 'futures robbed'

image.altText: A composite image of four photos of John Farnham from, left, in the 60s, 70s, 80s and 90s.

props.synopsis: While some schools might attempt a classic musical like Grease, this one has looked to Australian music royalty and, in the process, put on the show of a lifetime.

title.children: Belting out John Farnham classics and travelling through time — this musical is like no other

image.altText: Firefighters outside a building in a country town.

props.synopsis: Anthony John Kruger set fire to Geraldton's Department of Communities office in August last year after leaving his dog tied up there while seeking assistance for another issue.

title.children: Man who torched government building after his dog was impounded gets 7-year jail sentence

image.altText: A farmer named Peter Reid leans on the back of a ute.

props.synopsis: Australian sheep farmers say they're angry after a live export ban, looming for years, has been confirmed.

title.children: 'Tinging on anger': Australian sheep farmers in limbo after live export ban decision

image.altText: Red and yellow lights glowing above land with a plane wing in view

props.synopsis: While the weekend's incredible auroral display might be over, the Sun's antics may still be ramping up over the next few months. Here's what you need to know.

title.children: More stunning auroras may be on the cards this year, but a few things must line up first

image.altText: Tasmanian Catholic Archbishop Julian Porteous

props.synopsis: A letter to the parents of Catholic school students in Tasmania detailing a list of grievances by the archbishop, including that the church "cannot stand as we experience our freedoms being taken from us", is criticised by politicians and LGBTIQA+ advocates.

title.children: 'Nothing short of hateful': Letter by Catholic Archbishop to student parents criticised

image.altText: A courtroom sketch shows Michael Cohen being questioned by a woman as the judge and Donald Trump look on.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen directly implicates the former US president in a hush money scheme, telling jurors that his celebrity client approved hefty payouts to stifle stories that he feared could be harmful to his 2016 White House campaign.

title.children: Former fixer says he acted 'at the direction' of Donald Trump to arrange hush money

image.altText: A man wearing glasses sits in a darkened room

props.synopsis: A Chinese spy who is now on Australian soil has revealed his incredible story to Four Corners.

title.children: Eric landed in Australia and walked into the ASIO headquarters. 'I'm a Chinese spy,' he declared

image.altText: Artist Patricia Piccinini stands in front of her giant balloon creation, Skywhale.

props.synopsis: The often-divisive artist shares why her work is driven by a fascination for the frontiers of science and its potential — and her fears of what we're doing to the world.

title.children: 'I want people to love my creation': Patricia Piccinini on her mythical hybrid sculptures

image.altText: Close up of woman with red hair clamping nose shut with fingers, and staring into camera with furrowed brow.

props.synopsis: Smells wafting over from the neighbours might annoy you, but at what point do they shift from reasonable smells to unreasonable ones? Here your rights are explained.

title.children: What are your legal options when neighbours' bad smells waft onto your property?

image.altText: Waitress holding freshly cooked meals serves them to a table with a smiling couple.

props.synopsis: Almost one million Australians are working two jobs but many still struggle to afford shelter and food.

title.children: Skipping meals and working 80-hour weeks: Australians are holding down multiple jobs to ease cost-of-living pressures

props.synopsis: NSW shadow minister Matt Kean says nuclear energy is "hugely expensive" and not the path to cheaper electricity as his federal Liberal colleagues campaign for it.

title.children: 'Hugely expensive' nuclear a 'Trojan horse' for coal, NSW Liberal says as energy policy rift exposed

image.altText: Kim, left, wears a grey cardigan and silver gown and poses with platinum wavy hair next to Taylor, right, smouldering on stage.

props.synopsis: We don't blame you for focusing on little but Eurovision over the weekend. Here's the entertainment news you might have missed while you were dancing to Eurotrash bangers.

title.children: 'It's time to take our views away': Why fans are blocking celebrities on their social media

image.altText: A man lies on the ground as he watches his burning house destroyed by a Russian airstrike in Vovchansk.

props.synopsis: Russia targets over 30 villages and towns in Ukraine's north-eastern Kharkiv region after launching a ground offensive in the border region, forcing almost 6,000 to evacuate.

title.children: Ukraine acknowledges Russian 'tactical success' as it pounds 30 towns and villages in Kharkiv region

image.altText: the back shot of a woman sitting by herself on a cliff looking out into the horizon.

props.synopsis: The New South Wales government has proposed new laws for those accused of "serious" domestic violence offences to make it harder to secure bail.

title.children: Bail presumption reversed, electronic monitoring introduced under NSW government DV plan

image.altText: Two hands holding a latte in a black cup and saucer.

props.synopsis: Have you changed your coffee habits? One market expert says while the morning cafe cuppa continues, those on tight budgets are adding instant options to the mix later in the day.

title.children: Cafes feel the pinch as cash-strapped coffee drinkers look to instant alternatives

image.altText: A green sign on a building reading Foot and Thai Therapeutic Massage.

props.synopsis: A Federal Court judge has ordered the owner of a Canberra massage business and his company to pay a fine of nearly $1 million for the "systematic exploitation" of seven Philippine workers.

title.children: Canberra massage business fined nearly $1m for threatening and underpaying migrant workers

image.altText: A close up of a man having his hair cut by a barber with scissors.

props.synopsis: Charles Sturt University researchers say synthetic graphite made from hair and wool offcuts could help meet growing demand for the mineral, which is used to make lithium-ion batteries.

title.children: Human hair and unwanted wool could be turned into a vital component for lithium batteries, researchers say

image.altText: A person takes a photo of the aurora borealis in Vancouver.

props.synopsis: From Australia to the US — here's how the dazzling lights of the aurora australis and borealis were captured in each hemisphere in a rare spectacle.

title.children: Aurora borealis and australis dazzle viewers across the world for three consecutive nights of colourful wonder

image.altText: A multicoloured aurora over a lake.

props.synopsis: After this weekend's epic aurora australis display, the Bureau of Meteorology says there is still a geomagnetic storm underway that may produce visible southern lights in parts of Australia but the chance of seeing them is less likely.

title.children: Aurora australis displays still possible but less likely as geomagnetic storm level falls

image.altText: Walter Sofronoff dressed in court robes walks down a street. in Brisbane

props.synopsis: The ACT Integrity Commission announces an investigation into former Queensland judge Walter Sofronoff, who chaired the inquiry into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution.

title.children: Corruption investigation launched into conduct of head of inquiry into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution

image.altText: Protesters stand on the steps of a parliament building waving Georgian flags, one has a sign saying "no Russian law" in Georgian

props.synopsis: The detained protesters were among several thousand opponents of a "foreign agents" bill who protested outside the Georgian parliament to prevent members from entering the building.

title.children: Two Americans, one Russian citizen among 20 detained in Georgia as thousands protest 'foreign agent' law

image.altText: Katy Gallagher, sitting with Jim Chalmers, holds the women's economic budget statement

props.synopsis: Among a pile of budget papers deposited on the desks of journalists will be a booklet outlining how the government's financial plans will help Australian women. Here's what you need to know.

title.children: The budget will have a 'multi-billion-dollar' wage boost in two female workforces, but what else will be in it?
